creator: mweston@demandtec.com
text:
HSSF's only mechanism to write Excel files is to build the entire workbook in
memory and then write that out when it's all done. There is no way to write it
out a row at a time or even a sheet at a time.

I suspect this is hard, but I was surprised to not see any mention of any future
plans to address it, or even any other bugs filed on this subject. Unless I
missed something.

creator: dmui@apache.org
text:
This is something that's asked about...a lot.  The main issue here is that excel
places pointers to stuff further along, making it very difficult to stream.

The HEAD branch contains a memory-use refactor to help create larger
spreadsheets in the memory that you do allot.

I am also working on the HSSF, I am facing the same memory problem with HSSF. 
Is there any other alternative to HSSF which uses less memory.
creator: gopi.simhadri@tcs.com

text:
This is a limitation of POI. It seems to me that rather than re-opening a long
ago closed issue aksing for an alternative way out of scope a better way would
be to post a message on one of the lists.

Probably someone should address this by making an appropriate update to the
website FAQ with perhaps a rule of thumb about heap usage, and suggestions about
how to either make use of CSV / tab-delimited techniques.

I also suspect that a majority of the contributers to POI have been oriented
more towards the scanning of files, than the creation and/or maintenance of
Excel Databases.

(I suspect that someone will come along and close this.)
creator: dfisher@jmlafferty.com
yegor@dinom.ru
text:
Memory consumption has significantly improved in the latest versions of POI. There was a lot of refactoring in core classes, in particular, in handling BIFF records and formula tokens.  

Try the latest POI-3.5-beta4 or download daily builds from  http://encore.torchbox.com/poi-svn-build/

Yegor
